Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of woman, probably Hathor. Mould-made. Left forearm fragment. White coating preserved on some areas. Brown fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Pieces of large Isis-Hathor figure, probably local, commonly dated to the 3rd to 2nd century BC or Ptolemaic period (Bailey BM Terracottas IV: nos. 2995, 2997), though Late 4th to 3rd (ibid. nos. 2991 2992), 1st century BC (ibid. no. 2998) or even 2nd century AD (ibid. 3000; Dunand 1990: nos 327-355, dated 3rd or 2nd century BC to Roman) dates have been assigned to variants of this subject. Parallels from Cyprus (Karageorghis Pl.32.10 no.II(vii)196) and Tell el-Balamun (Spencer 2009, Fig. 9-20, from a Ptolemaic context). Probably locally made. Dunand, F. 1990. ‘Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte’. Paris 349. Karageorghis, J. 1999. ‘The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.V. The Cypro-Archaic Period small female figurines’. Nicosia: University of Cyprus. Spencer, J. 2009. ‘Excavations at Tell El-Balamun, 2003-2008’. British Museum Press: London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.153) (Phase 1)
